My great-grandfather was a veteran of WWI on the German side. He had a lot of things that are talked about in this video, he (most likely) had shell shock, which drove him to alcoholism. He was not always a good father, beating his children, especially his sons, with a belt. He had a bullet stuck in his leg from WWI, so he could never use that leg again. He did have a job however, being a tram driver.
But, as my grandmother and her sisters have told me, he hated Hitler. He had seen war and hated everything to do with it. It became normal to have a picture of Hitler in your household, but he is supposed to have said: 'That man will not enter this house! Not even if he'd stop by himself!' I just want to say with this, that there were also veterans who were tired of war and tired of Hitler.

It's worth remembering how absolutely desperate people in Germany were in those years. In a biography I read, a "middle class" mother was forced to take a small container to her maid's job to hide food scraps from the wealthy family's table so that her family would eat. She hid the container in her uniform. Of course, there was little or no work for anyone else in the family either. People thrown into that level of everyday terror and desperation often do things that their saner or less desperate selves would otherwise not do. I think the contrasts between Weimar Germany and now are pretty striking actually.

I also don't really like how absolutely no one ever says that some of those soldiers would have come right off the battlefield and "dealt" with the trauma of war by taking it out on their partners and/or children. And, I speak from experience, society would have supported them every step of the way in doing so.

looking back on the 5 day workweek is for sure. I'm sure we all have considered that automation will be impactful, but there's more. As technology advances , we will need more and more skills. I don't only mean education,, our hobbies will be increasingly important for our future potential. Hobbies are often some form of old manufacturing that is not marketable but might make huge impacts if available at the right time, athletics that might enable for rare tasks to be possible for some, or quests for knowledge that will enable groups to make "game changing" decisions. If only people could afford it, no one would ever be bored. boredom is purely a side effect of somehow not being able to spend enough money to do what you are interested in. If only people could pursue their interests, boredom would disappear, everyone would pursue skills (purely for entertainment), and suddenly when something needed to happen there would much more often be someone available who wanted to try their hardest to make it the best it could be. All of this will be crucial in order to make such technology available as could be possible. If we are purely limited to a grind, technology will be severely limited to things that are either profitable, or the passing interests of a few super wealthy, who won't practice.

European history describes the human events that took place on continental Europe. From prehistoric times to modern times. Europe has a long, volatile and culturally rich history.

Prehistoric European history began with the settlement of upright apes, Neanderthals, and modern humans. In ancient times, the ancient Greek civilization flourished in Europe, starting with the Minos and Mycenae civilizations, and developing the golden age from the 8th century BC, with the victory of the Greek people. Lap before the invasion of the Persian Empire, during this time the rich city of Athena had democracy [1], until a neighboring Hellenistic country, Macedonia, dominated Greece. With King Alexander the Great, the Macedonians expanded Greek civilization all the way to Asia, ushering in the Hellenistic era. [2] Later, in 31 BC, Emperor Augustus, after conquering the Hellenistic Kingdom of Egypt, founded the Roman Empire. [3] with vast expanses stretching from Turkey to Spain, from North Africa to Scotland. The expansion of the Roman empire laid the foundations for a series of empires that had never been seen before in Europe. After the decline of the Western Roman Empire in 476, European history entered a dark period, marked by the decline in education, social organization and by the tearing down of many troops. barbaric aggression, especially the Vikings, Avar, Magyar and Arabs.


Europe in 814.
The Middle Ages was marked by organized social reconstruction, mostly under feudalism, and the Northern domination of the Roman Catholic Church. In the east, the Eastern Roman Empire flourished, with talented Emperors like Heraclius, who was an outstanding general who defeated the Persians in the 620s. But it was from this very moment that the Arabs of Islam swept Europe and more or less defeated Heraclius, although the East Romans were still strong under Emperor Basil II, and in the Battle of Tours (732), the Kingdom of Frank (the Germans) defeated the Arab army. . [4] In 800, after the expansion of the thriving Frankish nation, conquering other Germanic tribes, King Karl the Great was conferred by Pope Leo III as the Catholic Emperor in the West against Eastern Rome. Although the Empire disintegrated after the death of Karl the Great, East Frank Kingdom - Germany - under the reigns of Heinrich der Finkler and Otto the Great grew, defeating the Magyar army which led to the Emperor Otto becoming Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire. [5] Before the power of Islam, the Crusades erupted, and eventually the Ottoman Turks of the Turks flourished and conquered the city of Constantinople in 1453, causing the Eastern Roman Empire to perish. 6] Meanwhile, Britain since the time of King Edward III fought with France during the brutal Hundred Year War. [7] The Middle Ages was followed by a revival, a rediscovery of classical values ​​and knowledge, with the revival of the two ancient Greek cultures, [8] and as a springboard for the Reformation movement. Protestantism, a religious and political movement that saw most of Northern Europe abandon the Roman Catholic Church and redefine culture and alliances across the continent, began a religious movement. to German theologian Martin Luther when he condemned the Roman Catholic Church system in 1517. He was determined to defend his thesis, [9] This period was also the foundation for his development. colonization, strengthened the Atlantic countries of the United Kingdom, France, Portugal and Spain and expanded European influence on the Americas, Africa, India and the East. This period was a turning point for the industrial revolution and a period of knowledge called the Enlightenment movement.

The second half of the 17th century saw Louis XIV's Kingdom of France rise to a mighty military power, with malicious intent to invade its neighbors, but he was stopped by King William III of England. [10] But in the 18th century, the influence of both England and France in Europe gradually diminished, and the Eastern European dynasties rose to become impotent. [11] With the mighty Emperor Pyotr the Great, the Russian Empire - Europe's largest country - defeated the Kingdom of Sweden, and became the hegemony of Northern Europe. Besides, the Prussian Kingdom - a small country then - also flourished, with the eminent King Friedrich II the Great, many victories of

My great grandfather survived the entire duration of the war and had experienced so much on the many battlefields he fought on (he served in Mesopotamia, Egypt and France), he caught malaria, got torpedoed and then lost a lung due to mustard gas in the trenches. Yet when he returned back home to Croydon, England the world he had left was not the same to the one he returned to and for the majority of the 1920s and 1930s he worked in so many random jobs just so that he could support his family. I think a big misconception about the 1920s is that it was roaring, but for the normal person on the street, especially in Europe, it wasn't - they didn't have time to party much as they had nations and lives to rebuild.
IDK why John mentions only the Communists as the opposite of Nazis, and ignores the SPD socialists, who were much more numerous than KPD - both in parliament, and in street clashes against the SA.

"Nothing spurs the economy quite like rebuilding infrastructure that you just blew up."

Not sure if John is being sarcastic here, but this is wildly and completely ignorant when it comes to economics. This is known as the fallacy of the broken window. There is no economic gain in destroying something and then rebuilding it. The resources that went into rebuilding could have gone into actually beneficial economic activities had those destroyed buildings not been blown up in the first place.

This is going to be buried, but anyway... I liked the old John Green better. His videos are as much about contemporary America as the subject he's supposed to cover. Great historic accounts are those that only at a small degree reflects the time they are told/written. A good example of this is "The Rise and Fall of the Roman Empire" by Gibbon. This book is 250 years old and are still read and seen as a cornerstone for our understanding of the time.
I suspect these videos won't measure well up to time. In twenty years this perspective will be seen as very old fashioned and kind of silly. If you have the view that the Nazi thugs trashed Jewish shops because they "threatened their masculinity" you have a very Freudian view on history. The real drivers were the combination of economic crisis, the ideology of nationalism, traumatized people from WW1 and the very real threat that communism was for the vast middle class, to their economic interests and to the institutions of the nation/state that their well being depended on.
By talking about this in the same way as some modern gender study professor would frame it just confuses the real issues. Germany in the 1920s are not like USA in the 2020s. Men did not force women out of the workforce because of "masculinity", but because of a generation of young men came back from four years in a trenches in the service of the "Fatherland" to an economy with 30% unemployment. This was in a time when the man was expected to be the breadwinner. Without work, they couldn't start a family. This would create dwindling birthrates and in time threaten the state because they needed taxpayers and soldiers in the future. A state were the population went down was seen as an unacceptable result for the state and for the people.
Jews were prominent in the leadership in many communist movement, this was one of the reasons Jews were targeted. The other reason was that anti-semitism had very long traditions in German nationalism going back to the middle ages and Martin Luther. Another reason was that Jews often were more prosperous than many Germans. In times of economic hardship some will try to rob those who are seen as better off.
We have to remember that the vast majority of the people supported Nazi policies in the 30s. You can't just take the popular zingers from modern discourse and use them to explain a very different time filled with people with very different experiences and ideas of what the responsibilities the state had to its people and the people to its state.


This is a very complicated issue. It is not easy to present it in an accurate way, and Green totally misses the target. Modern ideas are modern, they don't always fit when you describe these kind of situations. I'm sure someone gives you brownie points for your wokeness, but it's the wrong perspective. We need to understand the past, not explain it away by comparing it to unrelated issues of our world of today.

This episode is typical of Johny's cherrypicking of history. He completely omitted the 1919 Spartacist uprising of the famed Rosa Luxembourg and Karl Leibtnickt and subsequent Freicorp put down of the revolutionary, very formative in the history of the Nazis. Central Europe was riven by communist-inspired insurrections: Eugine Leviné in Bavaria, Bela Kun in Hungary, etc. The Mexican revolution in 1917 any, of course, the October 1917 revolution in Russia. From the perspective of middle-class nationalists, there was a great threat to them. Communist threats against them lead to the formation of rival paramilitary groups: the Sturmabteilinung of the NSDAP was mirrored in the Reichsnbanner of the SPD, the Stahlhelm of the DNVP, Red Fighters Combat league of the KPD. the famous SS, Schutzstaffel (protection unit) was formed to protect Hitler and his leaders from physical attack. Political factionalism would have heightened peoples' paranoia towards leftist groups. think of the ANTIFA of today: many people in the US many feel their free speech threatened and feel justified to retaliate. So that's why John dodges this issue. Another uncomfortable fact is that some of the communist leaders that lead these uprisings were Jewish, (like Luxembourg, Levine, and Kun, who were migrants to Germany and Hungary, respectively). This would have been a contributory basis for the NSDAP's attacks on Jews. Not legitimate of course, but diminishing the fear and hostility of the wider population to Marxist revolutionaries and blaming jobless men who felt their 'masculinity' threatened is a distortion of history and I think his perspective is coloured by contemporary US political culture.

The Nazis were never socialists. They deliberately appropriated this term to appeal to the masses, as socialism was incredibly popular at the time. In reality, the socialists, communists and trade unionists were their very first victims. In its first few years, the nazi party did have a ‘left’ wing, which combined revolutionary anti-capitalist rhetoric with the usual hyper masculinity, violent repression, racism and anti-semitism, but during the Night of the Long Knives they were massacred by Hitler’s wing of the party. After this, the Nazi party went full corporate.

Nte: The hyperinflation of early 1920s was a deliberate strategy by the German government to stiff France on war reparations. The strategy worked and Germany freed itself of the war debt in a few years and then grew until the great depression. Then they enforced austerity as a response, which lead to populism, which lead to Hitler. Germans post ww2 would proceed to not learn from this and instead learn the wrong lessons from both hyperinflation and austerity. Instead they champion swabian housewife economics and austerity today. The EU even has the same form of economics built into it's very rules and is enforcing austerity across it. And everything is going great, no problems or similarities at all to the early 20th century from similar causes here, no siree!

Most people here, have never known true physical hardship, and are quite likely expecting never to experience hardship, and that’s because they just cannot imagine not being able to afford a potato, let alone a pair of shoes, or doing backbreaking work for 10 hours a day six days a week. But it is totally possible in your lifetime for all of these things to happen If collectively we don’t pay attention to those who are in charge of us, for history does indeed repeat itself. Just be prepared.
